'''''Psathyrella aquatica''''' is a species of [[fungus]] from Oregon, first described in the journal ''[[Mycologia]]'' in 2010.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal | last1 = Frank | first1 = J. L. | last2 = Coffan | first2 = R. A. | last3 = Southworth | first3 = D. | doi = 10.3852/07-190 | title = Aquatic gilled mushrooms: ''Psathyrella'' fruiting in the Rogue River in southern Oregon | journal = [[Mycologia]]| volume = 102 | issue = 1 | pages = 93–107 | date=July 2009 | pmid =  20120233| pmc = }}</ref> It represents the first ever report of a [[basidiomycete]] fruiting underwater.

It was found by [[Southern Oregon University]] professor Robert Coffan in the [[Rogue River (Oregon)|Rogue River]] in the U.S. state of [[Oregon]].<ref name=SOU>{{cite web |url= http://www.sou.edu/cas/connections/connections0006.html |title= What Lies Beneath: A New Mushroom |date= January 1, 2008 |publisher= [[Southern Oregon University]] College of Arts and Sciences |accessdate= 2008-09-08 |url-status= dead |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080819151450/http://www.sou.edu/cas/connections/connections0006.html |archivedate= August 19, 2008 }}</ref> Coffan found the mushroom in 2005, and his colleagues Darlene Southworth and Jonathan Frank in the [[biology]] department at Southern Oregon University confirmed that the mushroom was a unique discovery.<ref>{{cite news  | last =siskiyoudaily.com | title =US: Scientists discover new mushroom species in the Rogue Valley | work =FreshPlaza  | date =January 25, 2008 | url =http://www.freshplaza.com/news_detail.asp?id=15146 | accessdate =  2008-09-13}}</ref>

The mushroom's stipe appears to be quite strong, and is anchored up to 0.5m deep in sediment, in order to stand up to the fast-moving river currents where it is primarily found.<ref name=":0" />
